Plant property where regulated substances are handled and processed is secured by fence and manned by security personnel at all times.

                                                                                                                                                                                          GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



     The Belle Plant processes follow the requirements of Corporate Environmental, Health and Safety Standards, PSM-S21, "Process Safety Management".  This standard includes and embraces the requirements of 29 CFR 1910.119 and 40 CFR Part 68.



The Belle Plant safety programs include:



Designing for Safety:

  *  A documented process technology system covering hazards of materials, equipment design basis, and process design basis.

  *  Extensive accident prevention and mitigation systems are strategically located.

  *  Applicable codes and standards are met or exceeded.

  *  Materials of construction are chosen to provide mechanical integrity.

  *  Quality Assurance ensures fabrication and installation in accordance with design specifications and proper assembly.



Maintaining our Plant:

  *  Maintenance personnel are trained and experienced.

  *  Contractors are trained and qualified.

  *  A work permit system controls hazards.



Operating Safely:

*  Operators are trained and job qualified.

  *  Technical resources are available and utilized as required.

  *  Operators follow approved procedures.



Auditing our Operations:

  *  Routine safety inspections are conducted.

  *  Corporate, independent and governmental audits and reviews are conducted.

  *  Process Hazards Analyses are conducted.

  *  Critical safety equipment is set up on a periodic inspection frequency to ensure ongoing mechanical integrity.

  *  Pre-startup safety reviews are conducted prior to staring up any new or modified equipment.

  *  Quality assurance of critical equipment ensures fabrication and installation in accordance with design specifications.

  *  All incidents are investigated and actions taken to prevent recurrence.



THE FIVE-YEAR HISTORY



     On December 3, 2010, two DuPont employees were exposed to methylamine, a chemical regulated under 40 CFR Part 68.  The employees were hospitalized as a precaution.  No other deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known off-site deaths, injuries, evacuation, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage have resulted from a release of any of the regulated chemicals currently at the Belle Plant from the covered processes under 40 CFR Part 68.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



Plant personnel are trained and equipped to respond to releases of the regulated substances.  The program is summarized as follows:



  *  Plant personnel receive emergency response training.

  *  Plant emergency responders are trained.

  *  Emergency response plans are in place.

  *  Plant participates in emergency drills.

  *  Critiques are held on drills and actual events.

  *  The Belle Plant is a member of the local emergency planning committee.

  *  The sites Emergency Response Team trains local fire departments and agencies in response techniques and methodologies.



If a Major Release Occurs:



  *  Emergency alarm is sounded.

  *  Plant Emergency

Operating Center is activated.

  *  Plant Incident Commander and emergency squad respond.

  *  Community emergency responders are notified  and respond as appropriate.



PLANT CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



As part of the Belle Plant process hazards review program, all processes are thoroughly reviewed on a specific periodic basis to identify risk reduction opportunities to improve safety.  As a result of these reviews, several items have been implemented or are in the process of being implemented to enhance our process safety management.



  *  Revision of operating control procedures.

  *  Piping changes to aid in emergency venting of certain equipment.

  *  Construction of diversion / containment to aid in preventing certain process chemicals from entering the waterway.
